newsitem.title: USA: US banking, insurance industries concerned by bill.
newsitem.headline: US banking, insurance industries concerned by bill.

text.p: The U.S. banking and insurance industries both said they were concerned by aspects of a financial-sector modernization bill passed by the House Banking Committee on Friday.
But, in separate statements, neither group expressed outright opposition nor said it would try to block the bill as it moves through the legislative process.
"While there are a number of positive provisions in the bill, we have deep concerns about several provisions, which clearly must be changed," the American Bankers Association said.

Bankers were opposed to provisions relating to bank insurance activities, in particular a special carve-out granted to the title insurance industry from the general provisions of the bill, the bankers association said.
Bankers were also opposed to a provision added by Rep. Maxine Waters, a California Democrat, which the ABA said would become a new, burdensome regulation mandating specific banking services.
The association also was concerned by an amendment that would enable commercial firms to directly engage in banking.
However, bankers were pleased by a provision that would merge the federal thrift and national bank charters and by the changes envisioned for the Federal Home Loan Bank System.
The Independent Insurance Agents of America said insurers were disappointed by a new standard that federal banking regulators could use to preempt state insurance consumer laws.

"When coupled with (other standards) the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency would have an array of avenues to attack legitimate state insurance consumer laws and regulations," the insurance association said.
The group said it was also concerned by a proposal to set up a National Association of Registered Agents and Brokers as a interstate clearinghouse for licensing insurance agents.
However, insurance agents applauded the banking committee's decision to add consumer protection provisions and other provisions of the bill, the association said.
